Ein bisschen lustig finde ich es ja schon, wie Reichen und Unternehmen der Arsch wegen #dwenteignen auf Grundeis geht. Und es kommen mantrahaft immer wieder die gleichen Bullshit-Aussagen:

  • ‚ÄûEnteignen schafft keine einzige neue Wohnung‚Äú (No Shit, Sherlock),
  • ‚ÄûBerlin ist auf Jahre √ºberschuldet‚Äú (Ihr habt euch nicht angeschaut, wie das finanziert werden soll, ne?)
  • ‚ÄûDer Markt wird das schon richten! MEHR NEUBAU!!!! WENIGER B√úROKRATIE!!!!!‚Äú (Jo, und wer soll sich den dann leisten k√∂nnen?)

Gerade beim letzten Punkt wird es interessant ‚Äî da hatte ich gestern ein sch√∂nes Video bei der GLS-Bank gesehen: Boden (und somit indirekt auch Wohnraum) sind im Grunde genommen gar keine handelbare Ware, weil er begrenzt ist. Mit anderen Worten: Der Marktmechanismus mit Angebot und Nachfrage und dem daraus resultierenden Preis funktioniert bei Boden gar nicht. Der Markt kann es also gar nicht richten, weil es kein Markt ist ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Sch√∂n ‚Äî und richtig! ‚Äî finde ich den Schluss, den Thomas Jorberg von der GLS-Bank in dem kleinen Filmchen aufmacht: Wir m√ºssen Wohnraum dem ‚ÄûMarktgeschehen‚Äú entziehen und Wohnraum bzw. das Nutzungsrecht (Wohnen) in Genossenschaften oder gemeinn√ºtziger Form weiterf√ºhren. Und das ist ja genau das, was die Kampagne #dwenteignen will! So, und jetzt lasst uns Vonovia und Co. ‚ú®vergesellschaften‚ú® ‚úäüíúüíõ
items.content_text:
Ein bisschen lustig finde ich es ja schon, wie Reichen und Unternehmen der Arsch wegen [#dwenteignen](https://www.dwenteignen.de) auf Grundeis geht. Und es kommen mantrahaft immer wieder die gleichen Bullshit-Aussagen: 

- ‚ÄûEnteignen schafft keine einzige neue Wohnung‚Äú (No Shit, Sherlock), 
- ‚ÄûBerlin ist auf Jahre √ºberschuldet‚Äú (Ihr habt euch nicht angeschaut, _wie_ das finanziert werden soll, ne?)
- ‚ÄûDer Markt wird das schon richten! MEHR NEUBAU!!!! WENIGER B√úROKRATIE!!!!!‚Äú (Jo, und wer soll sich den dann leisten k√∂nnen?)

Gerade beim letzten Punkt wird es interessant ‚Äî da hatte ich gestern ein [sch√∂nes Video bei der GLS-Bank](https://www.gls.de/privatkunden/deutsche-wohnen/) gesehen: Boden (und somit indirekt auch Wohnraum) sind im Grunde genommen gar keine handelbare Ware, weil er begrenzt ist. Mit anderen Worten: Der Marktmechanismus mit Angebot und Nachfrage und dem daraus resultierenden Preis funktioniert bei Boden gar nicht. Der Markt kann es also gar nicht richten, weil es kein Markt ist ¬Ø\\\_(„ÉÑ)\_/¬Ø 

Sch√∂n ‚Äî und richtig! ‚Äî finde ich den Schluss, den Thomas Jorberg von der GLS-Bank in dem kleinen Filmchen aufmacht: Wir m√ºssen Wohnraum dem ‚ÄûMarktgeschehen‚Äú entziehen und Wohnraum bzw. das Nutzungsrecht (Wohnen) in Genossenschaften oder gemeinn√ºtziger Form weiterf√ºhren. Und das ist ja genau das, was die Kampagne #dwenteignen will! So, und jetzt lasst uns Vonovia und Co. ‚ú®vergesellschaften‚ú® ‚úäüíúüíõ

items.content_html: For the first time in ages I went to a concert yesterday. It was outdoors, of course. There were four great musicians performing in the ‚ÄúGardens of the World‚Äù-park in Berlin, one of them being Alicia Edelweiss whose album I bought more than one year ago. Since then I spent countless hours listening to the music while wandering through the city.
items.content_text: For the first time in ages I went to a concert yesterday. It was outdoors, of course. There were [four great musicians](https://www.digitalinberlin.de/kiezsalon-gardens-of-the-world-2021/) performing in the ‚ÄúGardens of the World‚Äù-park in Berlin, one of them being [Alicia Edelweiss](http://aliciaedelweiss.com/) whose album I bought [more than one year ago](https://zeitschlag.blog/2020/10/27/155553.html). Since then I spent countless hours listening to the music while wandering through the city.

items.content_html: I had to take two weeks off and as there‚Äôs still a pandemic going on, I‚Äôve stayed in Berlin. Today the weather was great and I rode my bike for 75-ish kilometers ‚Äî that‚Äôs probably at least a 100 miles or so, I guess.
items.content_text: I had to take two weeks off and as there‚Äôs still a pandemic going on, I‚Äôve stayed in Berlin. Today the weather was great and I rode my bike for 75-ish kilometers ‚Äî that‚Äôs probably at least a 100 miles or so, I guess.

items.content_html: As this seems to be my food blog and poor man‚Äôs instagram, this is the place to mention this: For the last couple of weeks I‚Äôve had a huge craving for instant noodles. You know, these cheap convenience food packages from the Asian grocery store around the corner. Tonight‚Äôs dinner will be the DIY-version of that, kind of. Without this artificial seasoning and stuff. But with a truckload of instant noodles, of course.

I had some K√§ssp√§tzle yesterday. For the first time ever, I made one of my most favorite dishes completely on my own with nothing but flour, water, eggs, and some cheese. A ton of cheese, to be honest. Think of K√§ssp√§tzle as German Mac‚Äôn‚ÄôCheese with Swiss Cheese and special pasta.

It was great.

items.title: Spoti-bye
items.content_html:
In 2006 I bought my first CD ever: Stadium Arcadium by Red Hot Chili Peppers. A few years later, the Internet did its thing and I stopped paying for music for several years. Around 2012 or so I started using Spotify and had it since then with some years of Apple Music in between. Over all those years I discovered lots of great artists and listened to a huge number of songs, a lot of them are connected to people the once were or still are part of my life.

Six months ago, I heard a song by Austrian musician Alicia Edelweiss and bought the whole album instantly. You have to support artists during the pandemic, I told myself.

A few days ago I cancelled my Spotify-subscription. There are several reasons for this step:

  • From what I’ve heard, music streaming is a pretty bad deal for artists in general. You have to support artists, especially now. This might be more expensive, but I hope, that the music will be worth it, literally.
  • It feels like that I’ve listened to way too much music during the last years. Music became a background noise, I mostly listen to it during the day, during work. And while having access to music anytime is great, I somehow lost connection to the music itself, it’s nothing special anymore. I want to know the music, value its details, enjoy it consciensly, dance to it, make it something special.
  • I want to own my music. I want to have a CD I can share with friends, for example, even if I’m broke.

And now you have to excuse me. There’s some music that needs my attention. Or is it me needing the music’s attention? Does it matter?
items.content_text: In 2006 I bought my first CD ever: [Stadium Arcadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stadium_Arcadium) by Red Hot Chili Peppers. A few years later, the Internet did its thing and I stopped paying for music for several years. Around 2012 or so I started using [Spotify](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spotify) and had it since then with some years of [Apple Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Music) in between. Over all those years I discovered lots of great artists and listened to a huge number of songs, a lot of them are connected to people the once were or still are part of my life. Six months ago, I heard a song by Austrian musician [Alicia Edelweiss](http://aliciaedelweiss.com) and [bought the whole album](https://aliciaedelweiss.bandcamp.com) instantly. You have to support artists during the pandemic, I told myself. A few days ago I cancelled my Spotify-subscription. There are several reasons for this step: - From what I've heard, music streaming is a pretty bad deal for artists in general. You have to support artists, especially now. This might be more expensive, but I hope, that the music will be worth it, literally. - It feels like that I've listened to way too much music during the last years. Music became a background noise, I mostly listen to it during the day, during work. And while having access to music anytime is great, I somehow lost connection to the music itself, it's nothing special anymore. I want to know the music, value its details, enjoy it consciensly, dance to it, make it something special. - I want to own my music. I want to have a CD I can share with friends, for example, even if I'm broke. And now you have to excuse me. There's some music that needs my attention. Or is it me needing the music's attention? Does it matter?

items.content_html:
Usually I use my iPad to read RSS feeds or comic books or watch movies. Since a few days I’m reading the probably most famous book by anthropologist David Graeber. I really enjoy it and for the first time I take notes in the exact same book using Apple Pencil. While I read the book in German, I write my notes in English so that I can scribble them. Taking notes this way is really fun!

Back in school teacher always told us that you didn’t really read a book unless you wrote notes in it or marked the most important or interesting parts.

Oh, the book is also interesting to read, although sometimes it feels quite academic and I’m not used to this at all.
items.content_text:
Usually I use my iPad to read RSS feeds or comic books or watch movies. Since a few days I'm reading the probably most famous [book by anthropologist David Graeber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debt:_The_First_5000_Years). I really enjoy it and for the first time I take notes in the exact same book using Apple Pencil. While I read the book in German, I write my notes in English so that I can [scribble](https://zeitschlag.blog/2020/09/18/on-scribble-on.html) them. Taking notes this way is really fun! 

Back in school teacher always told us that you didn't _really_ read a book unless you wrote notes in it or marked the most important or interesting parts.

Oh, the book is also interesting to read, although sometimes it feels quite academic and I'm not used to this at all.

items.content_html:
Together with several hundred people I attended a leftist, antifascist demonstration in Berlin. Afterwards I watched the most recent episode of The Boys ‚Äî I’m so full of contradictions ‚Äî and wanted to do some programming now. But I’m way too tired and should go to bed.

All in all it was a great evening though.

But I'm way too tired and should go to bed.

All in all it was a great evening though.

items.content_html:
Together with my best friend I’m recording a German podcast about all things software development ‚Äî we’re both software developers. And every episode we drink a beverage we never had before. When we’re done with the drink, we rate it and the episode’s over.

Today I went to a local store called Getr√§nkefeinkost which was recommended to me by a former guest of the podcast. It’s a delicatessen store for beverages ‚Äî craft beer, special lemonades and so on. They also sell my favorite cola, Premium-Cola, a soft drink made by a small collective and I’m a fan of them, their drinks and their way of doing business.
items.content_text: Together with my best friend I'm recording a [German podcast about all things software development](https://codestammtis.ch) ‚Äî we're both software developers. And every episode we drink a beverage we never had before. When we're done with the drink, we rate it and the episode's over. Today I went to a local store called *[Getr√§nkefeinkost](https://www.getraenkefeinkost.de)* which was recommended to me by a former guest of the podcast. It's a delicatessen store for beverages ‚Äî craft beer, special lemonades and so on. They also sell my favorite cola, *[Premium-Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premium-Cola)*, a soft drink made by a small collective and I'm a fan of them, their drinks and their way of doing business.

items.content_html:
I’m struggeling with the new Sleep Schedule in iOS 14. I’m wearing my Watch to track my sleep, but I want the alarm to go off on my iPhone so that I have to stand up to disable it. This was possible prior to iOS 14, but now it looks like that I must rely on the Watch for alarms when using the Sleep Schedule. This sucks, seriously.

Thankfully the Clock-app is still there so tomorrow I will try again not to oversleep.

Does any of you know how to use this Sleep-thing with a Watch, but with alarms going off on an iPhone?
items.content_text:

This was possible prior to iOS 14, but now it looks like that I must rely on the Watch for alarms when using the Sleep Schedule. This sucks, seriously. 

![23BD148A-4B3C-4A22-9829-58F9193B8D56.jpg](https://zeitschlag.micro.blog/uploads/2020/96a66576f5.jpg)

Thankfully the Clock-app is still there so tomorrow I will try again not to oversleep.

Does any of you know how to use this Sleep-thing with a Watch, but with alarms going off on an iPhone?

items.title: On Scribble on iPadOS 14
items.content_html:
Yesterday I downloaded iPadOS 14 and wanted to test the new Scribble-feature that converts handwritten text to, you know, text. And so I’m writing this post (mostly) using my Apple Pencil and I have to admit that I’m a bit impressed. It works pretty well-ish. So far I’ve used an app called Good Notes to take handwritten notes, but there was no way to use the Pencil to enter text into textfields.

Although it’s nice at first glance, I’m annoyed by a couple of things:

  • The screen that introduces this feature is a mix of German and English as you can see in the screenshot I attached. I use my iPad in German and this might look like a minor detail, but to me, this is an important one. In my mind either nobody cared or QA failed and both cases make me a bit sad. Hopefully this feature is available for German, too. I will test it immediately ü§ì
  • The second thing is that the underlying machine learning doesn’t recognize some characters correctly or at all, yet. 1 and I are just one example, special characters are another. Maybe this improves over time?
  • When something goes wrong, like when a typo appears or so, I don’t know how to fix the error easily using the Pencil. I know that I can strike a word or whole paragraph to remove it but when it comes to changing just one letter, using the keyboard is far more convenient ‚Äî and faster. Sometimes the text gets selected instead of being removed, this is another annoyance.

In conclusion I’d really like to like Scribble and maybe I should just give it a chance? If it fails the test of time I still can go back to my beloved keyboard.

Edit: I just found out, that English and Mandarin are the only supported languages at the moment. Hopefully this changes in the near future as I really like this feature! Reading a book and scribbling notes in there is just great!
items.content_text:
Yesterday I downloaded iPadOS 14 and wanted to test the new Scribble-feature that converts handwritten text to, you know, text. And so I'm writing this post (mostly) using my Apple Pencil and I have to admit that I'm a bit impressed. It works pretty well-ish. So far I've used an app called [Good Notes](https://www.goodnotes.com) to take handwritten notes, but there was no way to use the Pencil to enter text into textfields.

Although it's nice at first glance, I'm annoyed by a couple of things:

- The screen that introduces this feature is a mix of German and English as you can see in the screenshot I attached. I use my iPad in German and this might look like a minor detail, but to me, this is an important one. In my mind either nobody cared or QA failed and both cases make me a bit sad. Hopefully this feature is available for German, too. I will test it immediately ü§ì
![](https://zeitschlag.micro.blog/uploads/2020/d3d5788f93.jpg)
- The second thing is that the underlying machine learning doesn't recognize some characters correctly or at all, yet. *1* and *I* are just one example, special characters are another. Maybe this improves over time?
- When something goes wrong, like when a typo appears or so, I don't know how to fix the error easily using the Pencil. I know that I can strike a word or whole paragraph to remove it but when it comes to changing just one letter, using the keyboard is far more convenient ‚Äî and faster. Sometimes the text gets selected instead of being removed, this is another annoyance.

In conclusion I'd really like to like Scribble and maybe I should just give it a chance? If it fails the test of time I still can go back to my beloved keyboard.

**Edit**: I just found out, that English and Mandarin are the only supported languages at the moment. Hopefully this changes in the near future as I really like this feature! Reading a book and scribbling notes in there is just great!

items.title: Sorry, Strava
items.content_html:
Until a few weeks ago, I used Strava to track my cycling and running. Seeing how far and how much I’ve ran really motivates me. Yeah, those ads for the Strava Subscription started getting on my nerves, but you know, giving kudos to friends and seeing some basic stats like the comparison among weeks made it worth nevertheless. Until a few weeks ago.

I imagine, that the investors told Strava to earn some more money, so they hired some growth hackers and then everything turned to shit. Those stats for example, how far I ran the past week? They’re gone. I gotta pay for them now. Like monthly. That’s a pitty, because to me, who runs once or twice a week, those stats are not worth more than like a buck or two.

Paying 60 bucks per year or 15 per month is way over the amount I’m willing to pay, so: Sorry Strava, I moved on and started using Activity with my Apple watch. There might be a small iOS-app incoming.
items.content_text:

Until a few weeks ago.

I imagine, that the investors told Strava to earn some more money, so they hired some growth hackers and then everything turned to shit. Those stats for example, how far I ran the past week? They're gone. I gotta pay for them now. Like monthly. That's a pitty, because to me, who runs once or twice a week, those stats are not worth more than like a buck or two.

Paying 60 bucks per year or 15 per month is way over the amount I'm willing to pay, so: Sorry Strava, I moved on and started using [Activity](https://apps.apple.com/de/app/aktivit%C3%A4t/id1208224953) with my Apple watch. There might be a small iOS-app incoming.

items.content_html:
The last couple of weeks have felt odd. I’m not sure about the reasons: Is it the pandemic? Stress? Some mental health issues? All of it? No idea. ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

This morning I noticed, that I didn’t listen to a single podcast episodes during this time ‚Äî and so I opened Overcast and listened to the not-so-secret plans of Marco Arment and _davidsmith and two short episodes of Darf sie das?, a very interesting podcast by an Austrian freelance journalist about feminism and society.

I missed this, to be honest.
items.content_text:
The last couple of weeks have felt odd. I'm not sure about the reasons: Is it the pandemic? Stress? Some mental health issues? All of it? No idea. ¬Ø\\_(„ÉÑ)\_/¬Ø

This morning I noticed, that I didn't listen to _a single_ podcast episodes during this time ‚Äî and so I opened Overcast and listened to the [not-so-secret plans of Marco Arment and \_davidsmith](https://www.relay.fm/radar/196) and two short episodes of [Darf sie das?](https://darfsiedas.at/), a very interesting podcast by an Austrian freelance journalist about feminism and society.

I missed this, to be honest.

items.title: From the mountains to the sea
items.content_html: I took another week off from work, filed my taxes and spent the last couple of days close to the Baltic Sea. Earlier this year I made a promise: I want to go there by bike. And so I did. I stayed at the flat of a friend and took care of their plants in exchange. On friday, I jumped on my bicycle and went off to the sea. After like 40 kilometers, I suffered from a flat tire in the middle of nowhere, but thankfully the parents of another very dear friend drove me back to the city. And so I spent the afternoon fixing my bike. On saturday, I even attended a small cruise for like 15 minutes. Then the ferry arrived at the final stop.

I still suck when it comes to beating the shit out of monsters, but it‚Äòs fun, even if I die literally all the time. And I can prepare food!

items.content_html:
In the last couple of days, I‚Äòve thought a lot about a former girlfriend of mine. I have no idea, where those thoughts have come from, but it has really hurt as I still miss her, even after a few years. I‚Äòm deeply sorry for what I did back then, for how it all ended, but I can‚Äòt change it.

To somehow deal with my regrets and feelings, I finally started to write a letter, which I‚Äôll never send to her. Writing down my thoughts and feelings regarding her has been a brilliant idea, I should‚Äòve done this earlier.

items.title: Going for a walk
items.content_html:
Since more than 180 days in a row, I‚Äòve done 10.000 steps daily.

I use Pedometer++ by _davidsmith to count them and this 180 days streak is now pretty important to me, I don‚Äòt want to break it. What I really like about this app is that it allows occasional cheating days: After six days in a row, you‚Äòre allowed to not have those 10.000 steps for one day without ruining your streak.

Especially as I‚Äòm working from home, this app has been even more important during the pandemic, as it makes me leave my flat at least once per day. Sometimes I still have to do some steps before going to bed, but this doesn‚Äòt bother me at all. Doing so is easier than letting the streak break.

Going outside for a walk or a run nearly always brightens my day. I guess, this has become some kind of a habbit now.
items.content_text:
Since more than 180 days in a row, I‚Äòve done 10.000 steps daily.

I use [Pedometer++ by _davidsmith](https://pedometer.app) to count them and this 180 days streak is now pretty important to me, I don‚Äòt want to break it. What I really like about this app is that it allows occasional cheating days: After six days in a row, you‚Äòre allowed to not have those 10.000 steps for one day without ruining your streak.

Especially as I‚Äòm working from home, this app has been even more important during _the_ pandemic, as it makes me leave my flat at least once per day. Sometimes I still have to do some steps before going to bed, but this doesn‚Äòt bother me at all. Doing so is easier than letting the streak break.

Going outside for a walk or a run nearly always brightens my day. I guess, this has become some kind of a habbit now.

items.title: Stressful vacation
items.content_html:
I didn’t work for four days in a row, as I only work four days a week and then I took one day off. This could have been som kind of short vacation, but I don’t feel relaxed at all, although I did some things I usually enjoy.

On friday, I cycled 40km to a nearby town call Potsdam, it’s the capital of the state of Brandenburg, that surrounds Berlin, the capital of Germany itself. I recorded and produced an episode of a podcast, I bought and read a book and yesterday, I attended a rally, but what really bugs me is, that I didn’t have an idea in advance, how I’d like to have spent these days. I didn’t have a plan and so the last couple of days were actually pretty stressful to me. Due to the COVID‚Äî19 pandemic, time flies and this weekend just popped up out of nowhere.

Next week, I’ll have to take an entire week of vacation and I’m already thinking about what to do. I’d like to have a plan, at least.
items.content_text:
I didn't work for four days in a row, as I only work four days a week and then I took one day off. This could have been som kind of short vacation, but I don't feel relaxed at all, although I did some things I usually enjoy.

On friday, I cycled 40km to a nearby town call Potsdam, it's the capital of the state of Brandenburg, that surrounds Berlin, the capital of Germany itself. I recorded and produced an episode of a podcast, [I bought and read a book](http://www.zeitschlag.blog/2020/06/11/yesterday-i-asked.html) and yesterday, I attended a rally, but what really bugs me is, that I didn't have an idea in advance, how I'd like to have spent these days. I didn't have a plan and so the last couple of days were actually pretty stressful to me. Due to the COVID‚Äî19 pandemic, time flies and this weekend just popped up out of nowhere.

Next week, I'll have to take an entire week of vacation and I'm already thinking about what to do. I'd like to have a plan, at least.

items.title: On "My Sister, the Serial Killer" by Oyinkan Braithwaite
items.content_html:
I just finished reading “My Sister, the Serial Killer”, the book by Oyinkan Braithwaite which I bought two days ago ‚Äî and I enjoyed it. Lots of dark humor, not a lot of hope, some dead people, some unexpected turnarounds. Thanks a lot for the recommendation, it’s a great book, I would buy ‚Äî¬†and read, obviously ‚Äî again.

Reading it in English went far better than I expected.
items.content_text:
I just finished reading "My Sister, the Serial Killer", the book by [Oyinkan Braithwaite](https://oyinkanbraithwaite.com) which I bought [two days ago](https://zeitschlag.micro.blog/2020/06/11/yesterday-i-asked.html) ‚Äî and I enjoyed it. Lots of dark humor, not a lot of hope, some dead people, some unexpected turnarounds. Thanks a lot for the recommendation, it's a great book, I would buy ‚Äî¬†and read, obviously ‚Äî again.

Reading it in English went far better than I expected.

items.content_html:
Yesterday, I asked for recommendations of good book, a thriller, something like that. Today I went to a local bookstore and bought ‚ÄùMy Sister, the Serial Killer‚Äú by Oyinkan Braithwaite.

It‚Äòs been my first English novel for quite some time.

Yesterday, I asked for recommendations of good book, a thriller, something like that. Today I went to a local bookstore and bought ‚ÄùMy Sister, the Serial Killer‚Äú by Oyinkan Braithwaite.

items.title: More or less unit tests
items.content_html:
Yesterday, I wrote some code, but I didn’t write any unit tests, like most of the time. I know, that this is a bad habbit and I want to get rid of it. So, first thing this morning: Writing some tests. What helped me was this book

And while doing so, I fixed two bugs and afterwards, a colleague of mine requested some minor refactorings. Thankfully, now that there were tests, it was a joy to change the code and not break anything.

The thing is: Whenever I write tests, I make some positive experiences from it pretty much right away. But when I write code the next time, I just don’t write tests ‚Äî again. I have no idea, why.
items.content_text:
Yesterday, I wrote some code, but I didn't write any unit tests, like most of the time. I know, that this is a bad habbit and I want to get rid of it. So, first thing this morning: Writing some tests. What helped me was [this book](https://leanpub.com/tdd_ios_gimme_the_code)

And while doing so, I fixed two bugs and afterwards, a colleague of mine requested some minor refactorings. Thankfully, now that there were tests, it was a joy to change the code and not break anything.

The thing is: Whenever I write tests, I make some positive experiences from it pretty much right away. But when I write code the next time, I just don't write tests ‚Äî again. I have no idea, why.

items.content_html:
A few months ago I heard in the news, that the local food bank needed volunteers due to the COVID‚Äî19-pandemic. Elder people do most of the work there, and as they’re prone to severly suffer from COVID‚Äî19, they had to pause their engagement. So I sent them an email and have helped them since then. Volunteering there has become a routine part of my weekend and I totally don’t want to miss it. I’ve meet some very friendly people there, you get some freshly cooked lunch and after a whole week of programming, it somehow feels like doing purposeful work: I’m making myself useful. Oh, and every time you help there, you get sweets.

It’s shameful, that those instutions have to exist, but that’s not the point here.

Elder people do most of the work there, and as they're prone to severly suffer from COVID‚Äî19, they had to pause their engagement. So I sent them an email and have helped them since then. Volunteering there has become a routine part of my weekend and I totally don't want to miss it. I've meet some very friendly people there, you get some freshly cooked lunch and after a whole week of programming, it somehow feels like doing purposeful work: I'm making myself useful. Oh, and every time you help there, you get sweets.

It's shameful, that those instutions have to exist, but that's not the point here.

items.content_html:
I suck at playing video games, I’m like really bad. But some of them are just great, The Untitled Goose Game, for example. I bought it for the Nintendo Switch a few months ago and every once in a while I spent half an hour trying to solve some puzzles. Sometimes, I’m successful, sometimes I’m not, but I’m still having a good time even when failing.

Nevertheless, console games are so freacking expensive. Stardew Valley for iOS is five-ish bucks, while you have to pay three times the price for Stardew Valley for Nintendo Switch. But maybe prices for iOS apps are just broken?

On the other hand, the most recent version of Mario Kart is sold for 60 bucks ‚Äî for one game! Who can afford that?
items.content_text:
I suck at playing video games, I'm like _really_ bad. But some of them are just great, [The Untitled Goose Game](https://goose.game), for example. I bought it for the Nintendo Switch a few months ago and every once in a while I spent half an hour trying to solve some puzzles. Sometimes, I'm successful, sometimes I'm not, but I'm still having a good time even when failing.

Nevertheless, console games are so freacking expensive. [Stardew Valley for iOS](https://apps.apple.com/en/app/stardew-valley/id1406710800) is five-ish bucks, while you have to pay three times the price for [Stardew Valley for Nintendo Switch](https://www.nintendo.com/games/detail/stardew-valley-switch/). But maybe prices for iOS apps are just broken?

On the other hand, the [most recent version of Mario Kart](https://www.nintendo.com/games/detail/mario-kart-8-deluxe-switch/) is sold for 60 bucks ‚Äî for one game! Who can afford that?

items.content_html: I just played some 0 A.D. on my 2018 Macbook Pro 13 and I‚Äòm a bit disappointed: The framerate was pretty low, it dropped to less than 8 fps from time to time and this wasn‚Äòt fun at all. The next time I will run it on the Windows low budget gaming computer again. With 60 fps.
items.content_text: I just played some [0 A.D.](https://play0ad.com) on my 2018 Macbook Pro 13 and I‚Äòm a bit disappointed: The framerate was pretty low, it dropped to less than 8 fps from time to time and this wasn‚Äòt fun at all. The next time I will run it on the Windows low budget gaming computer again. With 60 fps.

items.content_html:
In Berlin, the town I live in, there’re pretty strict lockdown-ish rules due to the pandemic. I haven’t physically met with neither my partners nor close friends for a few weeks now and to be honest: Next to going to the gym, this isolation is the most stressful part to me.

Nevertheless I’m sitting in a park right now, enjoying the sun, physical-distancing myself from everyone else. The next people are several meters away, everyone is calm, but you can feel, that something is different. Something’s in the air.

Spring and summer are the most amazing seasons in Berlin. Everyone is going out again, nature’s turning green again, the weather’s great most of the time, but you can feel, that this year, something will be different.
items.content_text:
In Berlin, the town I live in, there're pretty strict lockdown-ish rules due to the pandemic.  I haven't physically met with neither my partners nor close friends for a few weeks now and to be honest: Next to going to the gym, this isolation is the most stressful part to me.

Nevertheless I'm sitting in a park right now, enjoying the sun, physical-distancing myself from everyone else. The next people are several meters away, everyone is calm, but you can feel, that something is different. Something's in the air.

Spring and summer are the most amazing seasons in Berlin. Everyone is going out again, nature's turning green again, the weather's great most of the time, but you can feel, that this year, something will be different.

items.title: Diary and Meditating
items.content_html:
A few weeks ago, I startet to write an offline micro-blog. Some may call it a diary. You know, old-fashioned, unencrypted and handwritten. I bought a small, red notebook and started to write.

Around the same time I started meditating again. Two minutes a day, most days in the evening. And I found out, that medidating clears my mind: Whenever I meditate before writing a diary entry, it feels better and more structured than without meditating. It feels like self-care.
items.content_text:
A few weeks ago, I startet to write an offline micro-blog. Some may call it a diary. You know, old-fashioned, unencrypted and handwritten. I bought a small, red notebook and started to write.

Around the same time I started meditating again. Two minutes a day, most days in the evening. And I found out, that medidating clears my mind: Whenever I meditate before writing a diary entry, it feels better and more structured than without meditating. It feels like self-care.

items.title: Critical Mass in Berlin
items.content_html:
On last saturday, I attended my first Critical Mass. That‚Äòs basically some people riding their bikes through the city. 2000 people joined in Berlin last weekend. I realized (again), how much public space cars need ‚Äî and get. It‚Äòs time to build some proper bicycle infrastructure in Germany.

Tonight‚Äòs the next Critical Mass and I‚Äòm really looking forward to it!
items.content_text: On last saturday, I attended my first [Critical Mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_Mass_(cycling)). That‚Äòs basically some people riding their bikes through the city. 2000 people joined in Berlin last weekend. I realized (again), how much public space cars need ‚Äî and get. It‚Äòs time to build some proper bicycle infrastructure in Germany. Tonight‚Äòs the next Critical Mass and I‚Äòm really looking forward to it!

items.content_html: This morning I read about the Up&Go cleaners cooperative in the German ZEIT newspaper. I really like the idea.
items.content_text: This morning I read about the [Up&Go cleaners cooperative](https://www.upandgo.coop) in the [German ZEIT newspaper](https://www.zeit.de/die-antwort/2019-09/putzhilfe-helpling-gig-economy-reinigungskraefte/komplettansicht). I really like the idea.

items.content_html:
Yesterday I attended the Global Climate Strike in Berlin together with 270 000 other people. Throughout Germany, 1.4 million people attended that strike. But that exact same morning, the German government decided to do nothing against global warming again, but making life easier for rich people. They sell this “do nothing” decision as kind of “breakthrough”.

Dear politicians, I’m angry. I don’t want you to lower taxes. I want you to fucking fight global warning. What can I buy for all the money in the world, when there’s no world?
items.content_text:

But that exact same morning, the German government decided to do nothing against global warming again, but making life easier for rich people. They sell this "do nothing" decision as kind of "breakthrough".

Dear politicians, I'm angry. I don't want you to lower taxes. I want you to fucking fight global warning. What can I buy for all the money in the world, when there's no world?

items.title: Some random thoughts about what I like about ¬µ.blog
items.content_html:
Here are some things I really like about micro.blog:

  • I can write in Markdown.
  • There is a very low barrier to me: I can simply write down a thought or post an image. All I have to do is to start typing. I don’t even have to enter a title.
  • I don’t feel any pressure to perfect things. This is kind of new to me, although I’ve written blogposts for ~13 years or so.

To sum up: It feels like micro.blog has made me think about, what blogging is for me.
items.content_text:
Here are some things I really like about micro.blog:

- I can write in Markdown.
- There is a very low barrier to me: I can simply write down a thought or post an image. All I have to do is to start typing. I don't even have to enter a title.
- I don't feel any pressure to perfect things. This is kind of new to me, although I've written blogposts for ~13 years or so.

To sum up: It feels like micro.blog has made me think about, what blogging is for me.

items.title: On folding bikes and global climate strikes
items.content_html:
Since I’ve owned a proper folding bike üö≤, commuting and traveling is so much more fun. I have the bike with me all the time and ride as often as possible and whenever I have to get to a place I can’t reach with public transport.

I just decided to leave the train one station earlier, so that I can cycle home. Oh, and of course I will attend the global climate strike in Berlin tomorrow. üåç

Do you plan to attend the global climate strike?
items.content_text:
Since I've owned a [proper folding bike üö≤](https://www.brompton.com), commuting and traveling is so much more fun. I have the bike with me all the time and ride as often as possible and whenever I have to get to a place I can't reach with public transport. 

I just decided to leave the train one station earlier, so that I can cycle home. Oh, and of course I will attend the [global climate strike](https://globalclimatestrike.net) in Berlin tomorrow. üåç

Do you plan to attend the global climate strike?

items.content_html: I tweet in German, usually. On my tech blog, I write in English, but on my personal blog, it‚Äòs German again. And what about this one? I don‚Äòt know, I haven‚Äòt decided yet. Maybe both? Maybe just English, as it feels strangely somehow pretty natural?
items.content_text: I tweet in German, usually. On my [tech blog](https://zeitschlag.net), I write in English, but on my [personal blog](https://bullenscheisse.de), it‚Äòs German again. And what about this one? I don‚Äòt know, I haven‚Äòt decided yet. Maybe both? Maybe just English, as it feels strangely somehow pretty natural?

items.content_html: Here‚Äòs another one I took in Frankfurt last week. This time it‚Äòs without a filter.

items.content_html: Let‚Äòs see, how micro.blog handles images. I took this picture in Berlin and applied the “Pacific”-filter to it.
items.content_text: Let‚Äòs see, how micro.blog handles images. I took this picture in Berlin and applied the "Pacific"-filter to it.

items.content_html: A few days ago I decided to give AppCode a try. As it’s designed to be used with keyboard shortcuts, I switched from a German to a US keyboard layout. It’s much more convenient, not only for programming, but for writing Markdown, too.
items.content_text: A few days ago I decided to give [AppCode](https://www.jetbrains.com/objc/) a try. As it's designed to be used with keyboard shortcuts, I switched from a German to a US keyboard layout. It's much more convenient, not only for programming, but for writing Markdown, too.

items.content_html: Ach, ich fange jetzt einfach mal an. Manchmal ist anfangen wichtiger als es von Anfang an richtig zu machen. Und umziehen kann ich immer noch, das mache ich dann halt sp√§ter.
items.content_text: Ach, ich fange jetzt einfach mal an. Manchmal ist anfangen wichtiger als es von Anfang an richtig zu machen. Und [umziehen kann](https://help.micro.blog/2018/setting-up-wordpress/) ich immer noch, das mache ich dann halt sp√§ter.

items.content_html:
Ich bin noch nicht so ganz √ºberzeugt, ob ich nicht doch einfach ein Wordpress aufsetzen soll. Zum einen, weil ich es kann. Zum anderen, weil ich den Gedanken der Unabh√§ngigkeit mag: Wenn es mir irgendwo nicht mehr gef√§llt, kann ich einfach weiterziehen.

Vielleicht l√∂se ich dieses Problem aber auch einfach mit $5 pro Monat.
